comments.commentBody: Oops, make that "SchNeerson."  There are just no limits to my fallibility.

What's amazing is that this one guy is able to bring down so many multimillion dollar ball players because he was angry over a few thousand dollars.

Goes to show these players were reckless, entitled, and frankly, dumb in their actions. They thought they were invincible and they're getting exactly what they deserve.

How can any player who has whiffed as much as he has in post season play, be referred to as "best player in baseball"?
"Most overpaid" is more like it, even when he first signed for that much over that many years, which was just plain dumb from the get-go.

Again this same photo image of Anthony Bosch pops up as it has in previous articles on this drug story.
If one were to see it for the first time without any knowledge of the matter at hand, the reader would be certain of two things before reading one word.
1. He's guilty of something
2. Drugs are involved.
You can't.  HGH is very expensive.  HCG much less so.

Rules about chain of custody carry no weight in the adjudication of Bud Selig.

Through McGuire and Bonds this has been a tremendous problem for MLB, particularly in regards to the record books and the hall of fame. It has skewed the metrics, and messed with the standards.

Banning A-rod would have two purposes, 1) Censure for illicit doping, 2) Send a loud and clear message to lesser ball players that they had better stay off the juice or else.

can't get enough of this from Michael in Oregon...

"fascinating article, but...

stolen records
con man testimony
no chain of custody"

Amen to that.

However, at the same time the purely legal argument and the factual narrative only go so far. I feel for the game cause I love it. Yes we all have to deal with the big money hypocrisy of the business side of things and all of the downstream silt that flows from it. But c'mon people. Mariano on the mound, closing it out...good stuff.

Are we sure we can call them "medical records"? If it is true Porter Fisher is an invester and had full acess, it might be hard to make a theft conviction. I think judge judy would say the Bosch would have to be the one to "sue" to get the records back... just sayin

Bud Selig should do all of us a favor and suspend himself out of baseball "in the interest of the sport". This is the same guy that was cheering McGuire and Sosa.  How many other "clinics" does MLB knows about? They should have suspended A-Roid for 50 games without all this circus. I mean, the Yankees are going to bench him anyways if they make the post season. Now if they hand him a long suspension, this is going to federal  court where all the illegally obtained evidence that MLB have on A-Rod is going to be dismissed. This is your employers agent (MLB) buying your stolen medical records. Even if you get treatment from a witch doctor, that information is confidential.
The words "Florida" and "regulator" are mutually exclusive.
Bosch’s experience tells the rest of us shady characters to keep up on investor & partner relations! Politicians can turn a 180 on their friends with impunity but that doesn't apply everywhere else.
Beautiful family ..lovely story.. bound by your shared past and love. I hope my two children create something like you have built for themselves. Much continued happiness!

(Actually, this is Jane, but our NYT subscription is in my husband's name.) I've had inflammatory arthritis for 34 years. I was initially diagnosed with RA but my dr. now thinks I have a less destructive form of arthritis. Many long time autoimmune patients develop idiosyncratic symptoms and courses of disease. My treatment does not vary with my diagnosis. Like many here, I too take methotrexate along with infusions of a biologic.

I would like to hear more discussion about how and why people with one autoimmune disorder frequently develop others. For example, I have active inflammatory arthritis and Sjogren's Syndrome, which targets your tear ducts and salivary glands. I have also had symptoms of deep muscle pain resembling fibromyalgia.

Methotrexate also helps to control Sjogren's Syndrome. Fortunately, I tolerate mx pretty well. I only have negative side effects if I increase my dosage. If you are having neg. effects, why not try decreasing the dose or waiting a few days between doses?

What works for me besides meds: acupuncture, sleep, 400 mg. selenium, light yoga, enteric aspirin, and analgesic pads.

The pads are a recent discovery. I buy the large ones and cut them to fit. The capsaicin pads seem to work the best.

Thanks to NYT for this series of articles. I do not think RA and autoimmune disorders are rare, but I know they are complex. Such complexity deserves more intelligent discussion. Kudos!
If oral methotrexate causes unbearable side effects, switching to the injectable form may eliminate many or most of those side effects.
My princess defines camping as anything less than three stars.
This princess don't camp!

How about simply doing the right thing because it's the right thing.

When money is the most important thing, nothing else matters.
except for the heart damage that shows up years later.

And is Wall Street any different? Those guys game the system all the time, and cost millions their jobs and all of us tons of money. Yet there we see no convictions or even much attention.

You're crazy if you don't think those values are reflected by teh rest of society, including pro sports.
Anyone being paid $10 million a year for his athletic prowess, and who knows that something would enhance his performance, would be crazy NOT to be juicing.

I picked my heroes out when I was 15: Willie Mays, Abraham Lincoln and H. L. Mencken.
Mays and Lincoln have never let me down. Mencken gave me a spot of trouble when his diary appeared but, in the end, I decided I could never give him up. It's been good to have heroes who lasted,
Salman's all about how all our problems are the fault of those pesky workers "impeding" businesses with their demand that they actually get paid for their work.

Prof. K, you've appeared on Paul Salman's segments on the Newshour; surely you can communicate the importance of this matter to him and -- perhaps -- help them include real economic analysis in their discussions.

In another era, Rodriguez would have been as supremely larger than life as Ruth. Good judgment does not necessarily accompany talent. Rodriguez' downfall has been that his choices happened to include PEDs rather than the more mundane drugs, alcohol and women of his predecessors.

I am not excusing his behavior and he deserves the consequences of his actions.

Still, it is hard to watch this unfold and not wonder about the unfortunate fortuity of his hubris and the times.
Nonsense. Fans were more than ready to make gods out of Woods and A-Rod.  They shot themselves in the foot. Blaming every person of colors failures on white racism is getting really tiring.

Comments from bush hippy and sfd reflect today's ambivalent racial situation in this country.  A-Rod is a cheater and a liar and should be thrown out of baseball along with all the other cheaters/liars... white, black, brown, blue, pink...   Tiger Woods just doesn't win anymore and that is nobody's fault but his own.  As far as sfd's comment, I don't see the term "whites" anywhere in bush hippy's comment just the term "white man's game", which it is, so you are assuming it.  He wrote "haters" and You are the one who is connecting the words "whites" and "haters".  One last point, I don't know where you are coming from (sfd), but racism is alive and well in this country.

Like Tiger Woods, A Rod is an exceptionally gifted athlete.  Both have brought their sport to new levels of achievment and both engender an outsized dose of hostility.  Woods, a black man in an upper middle class white man's game, Rodriguez, a Latino who would eclipse every power category in baseball history plus gold gloves for defence.  Haters have trailed these men since their emergence as elite athletes and haters will not let go until Alex Rodruguez is forced out of the game and Tiger Woods loses a tier to become just a good golfer. Professional sports has become the surrogate for our dark side feelings about race and excellence.
Clear eyes, full hearts! Can't lose!

I certainly hope they find a way to rehire Coach Dunn. As a former teacher, I understand seniority, but he's performing an additional service. This is such a terrible conundrum. And it's really the kids who suffer because of all this mess. Please, let's start concentrating on our public schools to make them the best they can be.

If I were a GM who had the opportunity to draft one of three 18 year-olds - Derek Jeter, Alex Rodriguez or Ken Griffey Jr. -just based on raw talent, I would take Griffey in a heartbeat.Sure, his career was injury-plagued but in his early years in MLB, he was the best outfielder in baseball and went on to hit 630 home runs and over 1,800 rbi's. Do you honestly think that Jeter or Rodriguez would have fought through the same injuries and put up Griffey's numbers? Not a chance.
I agree, awesome story. Invest in kids and school now, they are our future.

The courage and determination of everyone involved here, students, parents, coaches, teachers, administrators, and union leaders, sets a very high bar for us all to aspire to.  However, it is beyond tragic that great schools in great cities are reduced to sacrifice and triple duty to survive.  May we find the will and strength we need to resist the gutting of our public life that the rich and greedy are inflicting upon us.

This is very sweet and we like to believe in the innocence of youth. But given the people who influenced him and who he hung with in high school, it's likely that A-Rod was already using PEDs in his teens. He was using them in 2001 and 2003. He was likely using them in 2009. He was using them in 2012. A-Rod's entire career in baseball has probably been PED-enhanced.

A-Rod is not the only villain in this tale. The Yankees likely knew A-Rod was a user or suspected it. They signed him anyway in order to win some ballgames. But now that A-Rod is no longer as productive, the Yankees are screaming that A-Rod is a cheat in order to try and save some payroll.

Then there is Bud Selig, who suddenly - after ignoring PED's for many years and then pretending that PED's were no longer a problem for many years more - has tried to, somehow, claim moral authority. A-Rod, Cashman, and Selig deserve each other. When they all leave MLB, baseball will, no doubt, be in a better place.

Thank you for the article on the Philadelphia schools' budget crisis. I hope Governor Corbett and the Pennsylvania House and Senate will be shamed into properly allocating funds to the district. As it now stands, even if these football players have a great season they won't have a counselor to help them apply to college. And what of the more than 100,000 students who play no sport? Children who live in Philadelphia deserve the option of attending a public school with full resources. Our situation is unconscionable.
